title: AI exposure predicts unemployment risk. (arXiv:2308.02624v1 [cs.CY])
abstract: Is artificial intelligence (AI) disrupting jobs and creating unemployment? Despite many attempts to quantify occupations' exposure to AI, inconsistent validation obfuscates the relative benefits of each approach. A lack of disaggregated labor outcome data, including unemployment data, further exacerbates the issue. Here, we assess which models of AI exposure predict job separations and unemployment risk using new occupation-level unemployment data by occupation from each US state's unemployment insurance office spanning 2010 through 2020. Although these AI exposure scores have been used by governments and industry, we find that individual AI exposure models are not predictive of unemployment rates, unemployment risk, or job separation rates. However, an ensemble of those models exhibits substantial predictive power suggesting that competing models may capture different aspects of AI exposure that collectively account for AI's variable impact across occupations, regions, and time. translated_abstract: 人工智能（AI）是否正在破坏工作岗位并导致失业？尽管有很多企图量化AI对职业的暴露程度的努力，但不一致的验证模糊了每种方法的相对利益。缺乏包括失业数据在内的细分劳动结果数据进一步加剧了这个问题。在这里，我们使用每个美国州的失业保险办公室从2010年到2020年涵盖的新的职业层面失业数据评估哪些AI暴露模型能够预测工作分离和失业风险。尽管这些AI暴露分数已被政府和行业使用，但我们发现单个AI暴露模型无法预测失业率、失业风险或工作分离率。然而，这些模型的集成展现出巨大的预测能力，表明竞争模型可能捕捉到了AI暴露的不同方面，共同解释了AI在不同职业、地区和时间下各异的影响。我们的研究揭示了AI对就业的影响具有多样性。
tldr: 存在一些关于人工智能（AI）是否导致失业的疑问，本研究利用新的职业层面的失业数据评估了AI暴露模型的预测能力。我们发现单个模型无法准确预测失业率和失业风险，但这些模型的集成具有较强的预测能力，表明不同模型可以解释AI在职业、地区和时间上不同的影响。
en_tdlr: There are doubts about whether artificial intelligence (AI) leads to unemployment. This study uses new occupation-level unemployment data to assess the predictive power of AI exposure models. It finds that individual models cannot accurately predict unemployment rates and risk, but an ensemble of models shows strong predictive ability, suggesting that different models can explain the diverse impact of AI across occupations, regions, and time.
